courses.name: Introduction to Viticulture and Enology
courses.description: This course will give a general overview of growing grapes (viticulture) and winemaking (enology) with an emphasis on Missouri wines and wineries.  This course is the first course in a sequence of courses in the viticulture and enology track of the food science degree program.

courses.name: Food Science and Nutrition
courses.description: Basic principles of science and technology as applied to the problem of providing safe, nutritious, and desirable food for man.

courses.name: Live Animal and Meat Evaluation
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 2114). The composition and quality meat produced from food animals is the driving component of livestock economic value. This course will teach the principles and procedures involved in evaluation, grading, selection, and economic value of meat animals and poultry and the carcasses they produce. This course is an excellent introduction and (or) prerequisite for all livestock production courses and will provide a baseline of information for students interested in livestock or meat judging.

courses.name: Dairy Products Evaluation
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 2131). Sensory Evaluation and judging of dairy products.

courses.name: Elements of Food Microbiology
courses.description: Introductory microbiology course stressing basic principles as related to foods.
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore standing. Restricted to Food Science Students during Early Registration

courses.name: Grapes and Wines of the World
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 2195).  Explores the world of wine through study of viticultural principles and practices, wine styles, classifying wine, the winemaking process and New World and Old World wine regions. Learn wine tasting skills and experience wines from around the world. World wine consumption, social and physical health benefits of moderate wine consumption.

courses.name: Seminar in Professional Development
courses.description: Readings and discussion related to professional development for the industry.

courses.name: Study Abroad: International Meat, Dairy and Enology
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 3190). This study abroad course introduces students to the meat, dairy and wine industries in Germany or in New Zealand (destinations are on a rotational basis).  Students will visit small, medium and large-scale producers and learn about differences in comparison to the US industries. May be repeated once for credit.

courses.name: Study Abroad: International Meat, Dairy and Enology - Honors
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 3190). This study abroad course introduces students to the meat, dairy and wine industries in Germany or in New Zealand (destinations are on a rotational basis).  Students will visit small, medium and large-scale producers and learn about differences in comparison to the US industries. May be repeated once for credit. Enrollment is limited to Honors eligible students.

courses.name: Kitchen Chemistry
courses.description: This course is targeted at current Food Science, Hospitality Management, Nutrition or Biochemistry students who wish to study the application of scientific principles to the practice of cooking. This on-line summer class assumes students have access to a working kitchen. Video cooking projects are submitted weekly. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Principles of Meat Science
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 3214). Study of the principles involved in the conversion of living animals to meat and by-products; efficient utilization of meat as a food.

courses.name: Principles of Dairy Foods Science
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 3231). Technology, chemistry and microbiology related to milk and its transformation into fluid milk products, fermented dairy foods and spreads. (2 hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory per week.)
courses.recommendation: One course in Chemistry or Biological Sciences

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture I
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 3240). Grapevine growth, development, selection, propagation, training systems, pruning, and harvesting; vineyard site selection, design, and development. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 1010 and one of the following: F_S 2195 or PLNT_S 2195 or PLNT_S 2100 or SOIL 2100 or PLNT_S 2110 or PLNT_S 2125.

courses.name: Physical Principles for Food Processing
courses.description: Introduction to basic engineering concepts used to process raw materials: Energy balance, Pipe flow, Viscosity, Heat exchange, Refrigeration.
courses.recommendation: one calculus course and one physics course

courses.name: Problems in Food Science
courses.description: Supervised study in a specialized phase of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Food Industry Senior Seminar
courses.description: The course explores the structure and the various branches of the food industry.  Emphasis is placed on industry trends and the manufacture of specific selected food products and their ingredients. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 1030 or equivalent, F_S 2199 or equivalent; junior or senior standing

courses.name: Topics in Food Science
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in the field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Food Chemistry and Analysis
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7310).  Structure, composition and chemical properties of food.

courses.name: Investigation of Food Properties
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7311). Study of the chemical and physical properties of foods and the interaction of food components.
courses.recommendation: F_S 4310 or equivalent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Chemistry and Analysis Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7315)The quantitative determination of the constituents of food.

courses.name: Food Chemistry and Analysis Laboratory - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7315). The quantitative determination of the constituents of food.

courses.name: Principles of Food Processing
courses.description: (same as AG_S_M 4330; cross-leveled with F_S 7330, AG_S_M 7330). Introduction to basic engineering concepts used to process raw materials. Principle topics include energy, material balance, fluid flow, heat transfer, refrigeration and freezing, and preservation.

courses.name: Technology of Dairy Products and Ingredients
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7331). Technology, chemistry, and nutrition of dairy foods as well as functional properties of dairy ingredients.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture II
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 4340). Environmental and biological factors influencing vine physiology and winegrape quality.  Irrigation, canopy management, pest and disease control, budgets and current trends in viticulture. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Processing Muscle Foods
courses.description: (same as  AN_SCI 4344; cross-leveled with F_S 7344, AN_SCI 7344). Materials and technologies for the manufacture of muscle food products from red meats, poultry and seafood. Experience problem-solving through further processing of complex ingredients and develop skills by practicing operations in a pilot plant facility.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture and Winemaking
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 4345; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7345, F_S 7345). This course will cover the basics needed by viticulturists and winemakers to understand grape vine growth and vineyard considerations along with winemaking principles. Viticultural topics will include grapevine growth and development, vineyard design and development, cultivar selection, grapevine propagation, training systems, and harvest and pruning. Winemaking topics will include sensory analysis of grapes, chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking, and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physiology and Biochemistry of Muscle as Food
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 4354; F_S 7354, AN_SCI 7354). Basic concepts in muscle growth and development of livestock evaluating the effects of environment, welfare, nutrition and genetics regarding muscle metabolism, physiology, and the ultimate condition of muscle as food.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or equivalent or F_S 3214 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Microbiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7370).  Study of bacteria, yeast and molds. Includes dominant flora, public health significance, characterization of organisms, examination of foods representative of major food groups, spoilage, preservation, food fermentations and physiological groups.

courses.name: Food Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7375). Examination of foods for microorganisms and characterization of major species.

courses.name: Sensory Analysis of Food and Beverages
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7380). Methodological principles of the sensory analysis of food and beverages.

courses.name: Problems in Food Science
courses.description: Advanced problems in a selected field of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Optimization and Management of Food and Agricultural Systems
courses.description: (same as AG_S_M 4390, HSP_MGMT 4390; cross-leveled with F_S 7390; AG_S_M 7390, HSP_MGMT 7390). This course is designed to introduce the student to the concept of layers and interacting systems within an operation and the analytical methods of modeling and simulation to make effective management decisions for optimal system design and function.

courses.name: Principles of Winemaking and Wine Chemical Analysis
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7440). The theoretical and practical basics needed by enologists/winemakers including sensory analysis of grapes; chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking; and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: 5 credit hours inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry or concurrent, or instructors consent

courses.name: Cellar Operations and Special Vinifications
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7441). The theoretical and practical basics needed by winemakers to supervise the operations of the winemaking, wine stabilization and packaging equipment.  The theoretical and practical basics needed by winemakers to make special wines including rose, dessert, carbonic maceration, and sparkling wines. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: 5 credit hours inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry or instructor's consent

courses.name: Internship in Food Science
courses.description: Combines study, observation and employment in an area of food science and nutrition. Written reports, faculty evaluation.

courses.name: Food Product Development
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7970). Capstone course integrating the various disciplines of food science to create new food products.
courses.prerequisites: Junior or Senior standing, or instructor's consent.  ENGLSH 1000 required if course is taught Writing Intensive

courses.name: Food Product Development - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Capstone course integrating the various disciplines of food science to create new food products.
courses.prerequisites: Junior or Senior standing, or instructor's consent.  ENGLSH 1000 required if course is taught Writing Intensive

courses.name: Food Quality Assurance
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7360). Capstone course integrating various food science disciplines to comply with regulations concerned with protection of the nation's food supply.  Applies practices to insure consumers of healthful foods.
courses.prerequisites: Junior or Senior standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Chemistry and Analysis
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4310). Structure, composition and chemical properties of food.

courses.name: Investigation of Food Properties
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4311). Study of the chemical and physical properties of foods and the interaction of food components. Lecture.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 4310 or F_S 7310 or equivalent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Chemistry and Analysis Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4315). The quantitative determination of the constituents of food.

courses.name: Principles of Food Processing
courses.description: (same as AG_S_M 7330; cross-leveled with F_S 4330, AG_S_M 4330). Basic principles of food processing, with emphasis on blanching, pasteurization, commercial sterilization, refrigeration, freezing, concentration, dehydration and packing. Impacts of processing on product quality are evaluated.

courses.name: Technology of Dairy Products and Ingredients
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4331). Technology, chemistry, and nutrition of dairy foods as well as functional properties of dairy ingredients.
courses.prerequisites: one Chemistry course and F_S 3231 or equivalent

courses.name: Processing Muscle Foods
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 7344; cross-leveled with F_S 4344, AN_SCI 4344).  Materials and technologies for the manufacture of muscle food products from red meats, poultry and seafood. Experience problem-solving through further processing of complex ingredients and develop skills by practicing operations in a pilot plant facility.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture and Winemaking
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 7345; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4345, F_S 4345). This course will cover the basics needed by viticulturists and winemakers to understand grape vine growth and vineyard considerations along with winemaking principles. Viticultural topics will include grapevine growth and development, vineyard design and development, cultivar selection, grapevine propagation, training systems, and harvest and pruning. Winemaking topics will include sensory analysis of grapes, chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking, and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physiology and Biochemistry of Muscle as Food
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 7354; cross-leveled with F_S 4354, AN_SCI 4354). Basic concepts in muscle growth and development of livestock evaluating the effects of environment, welfare, nutrition and genetics regarding muscle metabolism, physiology, and the ultimate condition of muscle as food.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or equivalent or F_S 3214 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Quality Assurance
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4980). Capstone course integrating various food science disciplines to comply with regulations concerned with protection of the nation's food supply.  Applies practices to insure consumers of healthful foods.

courses.name: Food Microbiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4370). Study of bacteria, yeast and molds. Includes dominant flora, public health significance, characterization of organisms, examination of foods representative of major food groups, spoilage, preservation, food fermentations and physiological groups.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 2172 and one Biochemistry course or concurrent enrollment

courses.name: Food Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4375). Examination of foods for microorganisms and characterization of major species.

courses.name: Sensory Analysis of Food and Beverages
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4380). Methodological principles of the sensory analysis of food and beverages.

courses.name: Optimization and Management of Food and Agriculture Systems
courses.description: (same as AG_S_M 7390, HSP_MGMT 7390; cross-leveled with F_S 4390, AG_S_M 4390, HSP_MGMT 4390). This course is designed to introduce the student to the concept of layers and interacting systems within an operation and the analytical methods of modeling and simulation to make effective management decisions for optimal system design and function.

courses.name: Principles of Winemaking and Wine Chemical Analysis
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4440). The theoretical and practical basics needed by enologist/winemakers including sensory analysis of grapes; chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking; and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: 5 hours inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry or concurrent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Cellar Operations and Special Vinifications
courses.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4441). The theoretical and practical basics needed by winemakers to supervise the operations of the winemaking, wine stabilization and packaging equipment.  The theoretical and practical basics needed by winemakers to make special wines including rose, dessert, carbonic maceration, and sparkling wines. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: 5 credit hours inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry and F_S 4440 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Internship in Food Science
courses.description: Combines study, observation and employment in an area of food science and nutrition. Written reports, faculty evaluation.
courses.prerequisites: One Food Science course and instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Product Development
courses.description: Capstone course integrating the various disciplines of food science to create new food products.

courses.name: Non-Thesis Research in Food Science
courses.description: Original investigations, usually in connection with one of the research projects of Agricultural Experiment Station. Written report required.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to Food Science MS Students Only

courses.name: Problems in Food Science
courses.description: Individual studies include a minor research problems.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to Food Science MS Students only

courses.name: Seminar in Food Science
courses.description: Provides students with opportunities for development in depth of advanced aspects of food science through reviews of research in progress and of current scientific publications.

courses.name: Research in Food Science
courses.description: Original investigations, usually in connection with one of the research projects of Agricultural Experiment Station. Written report required.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to Food Science MS Students Only

courses.name: Strategic Human Resource Management in Hospitality
courses.description: This course is designed to help graduate students pursuing a managerial position in the Hospitality Industry to understand the value and the competitive advantage that strategic human resource management provide.
courses.prerequisites: HSP MGMT 4253 or equivalent and instructors consent

courses.name: Service Operations Management: Revenue Management
courses.description: This course offers an opportunity for students to learn the theory, concepts, and knowledge applied in service operations management. Students will find them useful in trying to cope with the dilemmas faced by operating managers in the hospitality industry. Especially, the course focuses on revenue management.

courses.name: Advanced Hospitality Marketing
courses.description: This course provides students with an advanced-level view of marketing strategies in the hospitality.  The course encompasses analytical readings on segmentation and positioning, relationship marketing, marketing-mix development, and other strategic approaches applicable to hospitality industries.
courses.prerequisites: HSP_MGMT 4273 or equivalent and instructors consent

courses.name: Topics in Food Science
courses.description: Specialized topics in the area of food science and nutrition.

courses.name: Research Methods in Food Science
courses.description: (same as BIOL_EN 8402). Introduction to research. Defining research problems, developing hypotheses, searching scientific literature, designing experiments, presenting data, writing scientific papers and theses, making oral presentations.

courses.name: Advanced Food Microbiology and Biotechnology
courses.description: Covers basic principles in biotechnology and applied food microbiology, including current topics of interest in food biotechnology.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Microbiology of Foods
courses.description: Principles of microbial physiology, taxonomy, analytical methods applied to study of microorganisms added to foods and those causing food spoilage or food-borne illness. Roles of microorganisms in manufacture/distribution of foods.

courses.name: Food Chemistry II
courses.description: Study of chemical content of food, emphasizing aspects that exist uniquely in food.

courses.name: Meat Quality
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8414). Discussion of factors affecting meat quality in beef, pork, lamb and poultry. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Field Training in Food Science
courses.description: Internships and/or field experiences under supervision.

courses.name: Meat Investigations
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8424). Discussion of literature, special reports, assigned readings, techniques, interpretation of results.

courses.name: Functional Foods and Nutraceuticals
courses.description: Principles and challenges involved in developing foods with health benefits beyond basic nutrition; efficacy, safety, regulatory and marketing aspects of functional foods and nutraceutical; current controversies and evidence of therapeutic properties of functional foods and Dietary supplements. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 3630 or equivalent and F_S 4310 or equivalent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Biopolymers
courses.description: Study of physical, chemical, and functional properties of food biopolymers and their applications in food and other industries. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Food Science
courses.description: Individual studies includes minor research problems.

courses.name: Seminar in Food Science
courses.description: Provides students with opportunities for development in depth of advanced aspects of food science through reviews of research in progress and of current scientific publications.

courses.name: Research in Foods Science
courses.description: Original investigation of advanced nature, leading to dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Research Methods in Food and Hospitality Systems
courses.description: This course provides doctoral students with introduction and review of research methods available for use in the study of food science, hospitality management and agricultural system management.  Hence, the emphasis of this course is on empirical studies in the field, and will examine research conducted by scholars in the  academic area.  This course assists as baseline preparation for graduate students' continuing work in the graduate program.  Specifically, the course provides students with knowledge and research experience in regard to 1) research fundamentals and backgrounds, 2) types of research, and 3) data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: Introductory research method course or statistics course; instructor's consent required

courses.name: Advanced Food Quality Assurance
courses.description: Analyzes concepts of integrating laws, TQM and statistical process control into HACCP and ISO systems required for the quality of the global food industry.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 4980 or equivalent and one Statistics course

courses.name: Advanced Food Technology
courses.description: To understand the physical and chemical changes that occur during the processing and storage of food; study the quality and safety issues of foods and learn traditional and recent advances in food science and technology.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 4310, or equivalent or instructor's consent
